nodes.text: Land price can contain a rational bubble even when the observed housing rent to price ratio is constant and non-vanishing, because one must distinguish rent accruing to land from rent accruing to housing structure
We analyze a two-period overlapping generations economy with consumption good and housing service to study land bubbles attached to dividend-paying assets
Separate housing rent (price of housing service) from pure land rent (land dividend); failure to separate them can lead to mistaken rejection of land bubbles when housing rent yield is stationary

Use Cobb-Douglas preferences for agents, a representative firm producing housing via construction material and land with a homogeneous, concave production function satisfying an Inada-type condition, and standard market clearing and profit maximization
Solve equilibrium: Cobb-Douglas demand yields expenditure shares (beta_y, beta_o, beta_h) and land price equals beta_o times endowment et, characterizing equilibrium allocations and prices
Define land dividend Dt as marginal product of land FX evaluated at equilibrium construction Mt, and housing rent rt linked to marginal product of material FM
Aggregate rent to price ratio rtht/Pt is constant and equals beta_h divided by beta_o (Proposition 1)
Equilibrium construction Mt is uniquely determined by the condition F/FM(Mt,1)=beta_h et, and existence and uniqueness follow from properties of F
Land dividend yield Dt/Pt equals (beta_h/beta_o) times FX/F evaluated at (Mt,1), linking dividend yield behavior to production function ratios
There exists a unique equilibrium characterized by the derived closed form conditions; a land bubble occurs if and only if the sum over time of FX/F(Mt,1) is finite (Proposition 2)
Apply Bubble Characterization Lemma: an asset price exhibits a bubble iff the infinite sum of dividend yields Dt/Pt converges
Specialize to CES production with elasticity of substitution sigma>1: asymptotic expressions show FX/F behaves like a constant times M^{1/sigma -1} and FM/F behaves like M^{-1}

For CES with sigma>1, there is a land bubble iff the sum over t of et^{1/sigma -1} is finite; under sustained economic growth et ~ G^t with G>1 this condition holds and land bubbles inevitably emerge (Proposition 3 and corollary)
Proofs: show sufficiency by bounding FX/F above using large Mt asymptotics and summability, and necessity by lower bounding FX/F and summing under the bubble condition
Conclusion: Empirical stationarity of the housing rent to price ratio does not rule out land bubbles; empirical work must separate structure rent from pure land rent to assess land bubble existence
